titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Mark Bloch Postal Art Network (PAN) Archive
1978-2007
MSS 170
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rachel Greer and Sana Masood, 2015. Data entry by Sana Masood, 2015.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2016-02-10T15:08-0500

did.unittitle: Mark Bloch Postal Art Network (PAN) Archive
did.abstract: Mark Bloch is an American artist and writer whose work uses both visuals and text to explore ideas of long distance communication. This collection contains thousands of examples of original “mail art” sent to and collected by Mark Bloch in New York City from all fifty American states and dozens of countries in the form of objects, envelopes, artwork, and enclosures as well as publications, postcards and announcements documenting avant-garde cultural activities in various media, during the years 1978 to 2013.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into the following series and subseries:

Series I: Mail Art
Series II: Non-Mail Art Periodicals, Announcements and Flyers
Series III: Objects
Series IV: Serials
Series V: Books
Series VI: Personal
Series VII: Junk Mail
Oversize Series I: Mail Art
Oversize Series II: Junk Mail
Oversize Series III: Objects
Oversize Series IV: Serials
Arrangement varies by series. Material in the oversize series was separated based on size. Please see each particular series for the arrangement of that particular section of the collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Mark Bloch is an American fine artist and writer whose work uses visuals and text to explore ideas around long distance communication.

Born in 1956, Bloch grew up in the suburbs of Cleveland and Akron, Ohio, and attended Kent State University, where he received his B.A. degree in Broadcasting. In 1977, after studying traditional art forms as well as performance and video art, Bloch discovered the international mail art network and eventually began to correspond with most of the key figures in that far flung collection of artists worldwide. While living in Southern California from 1978-1982, Bloch supported himself by making slide shows for corporate clients until he moved to New York City in 1982. He was a central character in the activities of the New York group of mail art enthusiasts at that time, and a member of Ray Johnson’s New York Correspondence School. Bloch’s work with an extended version of the mail art network continues today on the Internet. In 1989, Bloch began his experimental foray into the digital space when he founded Panscan, part of a text-based teleconferencing system, the first online art discussion group in New York City.

For 35 years, using the international postal system as a distribution network for his art, Bloch reached out to thousands of artists and cultural workers all over the world, exchanging publications, objects, postcards, letters and artifacts and amassing an extensive collection that now serves as a significant barometer of the culture of the late 1970s, 1980s and 1990s. While Bloch’s work now resides in hundreds of personal and public archives internationally as well as many important institutions and museums, his archive of mail art reflects the experimental circumventing and strategic navigation of such institutions in favor of the Do It Yourself culture of the late 20th century, which has become commonplace in the digital age.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is currently being processed and is not open to researchers.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Mark Bloch donated this collection to the Fales Library & Special Collection in 2005.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains thousands of examples of original “mail art” sent to and collected by Mark Bloch in New York City from all fifty states and dozens of countries in the form of objects, envelopes, artwork, and enclosures as well as publications, postcards and announcements documenting avant garde cultural activities in various media during the years 1978 to 2013.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Mark Bloch Postal Art Network (PAN) Archive; MSS 170; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Collection was processed between 2008 and 2015 by Kelsi Evans, Lawrence Giffin, Nicholas Martin, Rhyannon J. Rodriguez, Laurainne Ojo-Ohikuare, Rachel Greer and Sana Masood. Donor Mark Bloch advised on some arrangement decisions. Much of the collection has been housed at the folder level, but is described at the box level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series comprises the bulk of the collection and contains mail art sent back and forth between Mark Bloch and thousands of artists in all 50 states and dozens of countries. The series includes mail art in myriad forms: letters, postcards, zines, pamphlets, enclosures, collages, drawings, and paintings, among other media.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has been arranged into three subseries by format:

Subseries A: Correspondence [General Mail Art]
Subseries B: Postcards
Subseries C: Empty Envelopes
Subseries A is arranged alphabetically by geographical place name, based on the postmark of the piece of mail art. Subseries B and C are arranged by size.

did.unittitle: Series II: Non-Mail Art Periodicals, Announcements and Flyers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series consists of periodicals, announcements, flyers, catalogs and other mailed material collected by Mark Bloch over four decades.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has been arranged alphabetically by category.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains objects that were mailed to Mark Bloch as part of the Mail Art Network.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by object size.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains serials (magazines, zines, newspapers, catalogs, and newsletters) that Mark Bloch collected between 1978 and 2013. Strengths of this series include documentation of the small magazine culture from the downtown scene in the last decades of the twentieth century, including a zine written by Donna Tartt.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by serial title.
